title: Ed Miliband says Brexit chaos has been a ‘nightmare distraction’
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Ed Miliband has branded Brexit a ‘nightmare’ diverting attention from other crucial issues facing the country.

The former Labour leader, who also ruled out becoming a caretaker prime minister, suggested people would look back on the climate crisis in a decade and consider it ‘much more important’ than Britain leaving the EU.

Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, Mr Miliband said: ‘In 2015, I feared that the referendum would distract attention from other issues.

‘I don’t think in my worst nightmares I thought that it would do it to this extent.’

Reports in the last few days had singled out Mr Miliband as a possible candidate to head up a government of national unity – if opposition MPs topple Boris Johnson’s government and refuse to back Jeremy Corbyn.

Ed Miliband has been touted as a possible leader of an interim government (Picture: Getty images)

The Labour MP says Brexit’s impact has surpassed his ‘worst nightmares’

Others touted as potential leaders include Ken Clarke and Harriet Harman – the oldest serving male and female MPs – and John Bercow, the Speaker of the House of Commons.

Bus driver praised after taking detour to help 'sobbing' little girl get home

Yet Mr Miliband was reportedly being spoken about this week as a candidate who could gather wider support and be acceptable to the Labour leadership on a temporary basis.

But, asked if he would rule out leading an interim government, he said: ‘Definitely.

‘I can honestly say (the story) was the first I heard about it.’

Opposition MPs in a so-called ‘Rebel Alliance’ are hoping to oust Mr Johnson as prime minister and install a leader that parties of different stripes can get behind – but have so far been unable to agree on a candidate.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson has refused to back Mr Corbyn, who Labour insist should be put in charge under such circumstances.

Speaking about the fall out from the decision to leave the EU, while meeting Extinction Rebellion protesters near parliament, Mr Miliband continued: ‘What concerns me is the country and how divided the country is.

Mr Miliband, who was speaking while meeting Extinction Rebellion protesters, believes climate change will soon be seen as more important than Brexit (Picture: Harrison Jones)

‘If I think about the climate emergency I honestly think in 10 years time people will look back and say, “well that’s much more important than Brexit, much more important”, but it is blotted out by what has happened over the last three and a half years.’

The Doncaster MP, who opposed the idea of a referendum before losing the 2015 general election, has previously voted in favour of a customs union, a ‘Norway’ type exit and a confirmatory referendum.

Mr Miliband – who was tipped to win the 2015 general election but resigned as party leader after David Cameron’s Conservatives won a majority – campaigned to remain in the 2015 referendum.

His office have been asked to clarify his current position on Brexit but did not immediately respond.

description: Former Labour leader rules out being caretaker Prime Minister in interim government and says climate change 'much more important' than Brexit.
